Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A thin uniform disk of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a string wrapped around its edge and attached to the ceiling. The bottom of the disk is at a height <math alttext="3 uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the floor, as shown above. The disk is released from rest. The rotational inertia of a disk around its center is <math alttext="I equals, one half M, uppercase R squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) On the circle below that represents the disk, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the disk. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the disk, beginning at the point where the force is exerted on the disk. The dot is at the center of the disk.

(b) When released from rest, the disk falls and the string unwinds. The force the string exerts on the disk is <math alttext="F sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the gravitational force exerted on the disk is <math alttext="F sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following expressions correctly relates <math alttext="F sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as the disk falls?

<math alttext="F sub T is less than F sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>      <math alttext="F sub T equals F sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>      <math alttext="F sub T is greater than F sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

Justify your answer.

(c) Express all answers in terms of <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

i. Derive an expression for the acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the disk as it falls.

ii. Derive an expression for the time <math alttext="delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that it takes the disk to reach the ground.

iii. Derive an expression for the rotational kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub rotation" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>rot</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of the disk at the instant it reaches the ground.

(d) A very narrow wedge is cut out of the thin uniform disk of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. If <math alttext="lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance from the tip of the wedge, then the linear mass density of the wedge can be expressed as follows:

<math alttext="lambda of r, equals the fraction with numerator M lowercase r, and denominator 25 uppercase R squared, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>25</mn><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

i. Using integral calculus, derive an expression for the rotational inertia of the wedge around its tip.
ii. Derive an expression for the rotational inertia of the modified disk (i.e., the disk after the narrow wedge is cut out) around its original center.
